content.text: For the graph in Fig. 1.1, match each letter, R, S and T, with the motion at that point
Draw **one** line from each letter to the correct description. One has been done for you
Determine the speed of the car at time \(= 4.0 \text{s}\)
Determine the distance moved by the car from time \(= 16.0 \text{s}\) to time \(= 20.0 \text{s}\)
distance moved = .........m
Define the term velocity
Fig. 1.1 shows the speedâ€“time graph for a car
Fig. 1.1
The height of the stack of masses is 5.4 cm
Calculate the average thickness of **one** mass
average thickness of **one** mass = .........\(cm\)
Fig. 2.2 shows the masses, a measuring cylinder and a beaker containing some water
The student uses the equipment in Fig. 2.2 to determine the total volume of the six masses
Describe a method that the student uses
A student places six \(100\mathrm{g}\) masses in a stack, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Calculate the resultant horizontal force on the boat in Fig. 3.1
direction of resultant force
Suggest what causes the 80 N force on the boat in Fig. 3.1
Another boat is travelling and the horizontal forces on this boat are balanced
Describe the horizontal motion of this boat
Fig. 3.2 shows the wheel used to steer a boat
A force of \(60 \text{N}\) acts at a perpendicular distance of \(50 \text{cm}\) from the wheel's pivot
Calculate the moment of the \(60 \text{N}\) force about the pivot. Include the unit
moment =
unit
Fig. 3.1 shows the horizontal forces acting on a boat
State two reasons, apart from cost, for reducing the amount of fossil fuel burned
Describe how a hydroelectric power station generates electrical power
Hydroelectric power stations are expensive to build
State two other disadvantages of using a hydroelectric power station to generate electrical power
The government plans to build some wind turbines. The government plans to store some of the electrical energy generated by the wind turbines
Suggest one method of storing the electrical energy generated by a wind turbine
The government of a country decides to reduce the amount of fossil fuel burned for generating electrical power
Describe the arrangement, separation and motion of gas particles
A force of \(30 \text{N}\) pushes the piston into the container for a distance of \(0.18 \text{m}\)
Calculate the work done by the \(30 \text{N}\) force
work done = .........J
When the piston moves into the container, the temperature of the gas does **not** change
Describe and explain any change in the pressure on the walls of the container
Fig. 5.1 shows some gas in a container with a piston. The piston can move into the container
Describe how the student can compare the conduction of thermal energy through the rods in Fig. 6.1
Calculate the frequency of the infrared waves
frequency = .........Hz
State the name of a region of the electromagnetic spectrum which has a wavelength longer than the wavelength of infrared. Give **one** use of the radiation in this region
region
use
The Bunsen burner emits infrared waves
The infrared waves have a wavelength of \(2.0 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\)
The velocity of the infrared waves is \(3.0 \times 10^{8} \text{m/s}\)
A student wants to compare the conduction of thermal energy through rods made of iron, copper, glass and aluminium. Each rod is coated with wax
Fig. 6.1 shows the equipment that the student uses
Indicate the angle of reflection by drawing a letter R on Fig. 7.1
State the size of the angle of reflection in Fig. 7.1
angle of reflection = .........Â°
Fig. 7.1 shows a ray of light striking a plane mirror. The ray is reflected as shown
The angle of incidence for the ray of light is \(40^{\circ}\)
On Fig. 7.2, locate the image of O by continuing the path of each ray
Draw an arrow to represent the image of O
An object O is placed to the left of a thin converging lens. \(\mathsf{F}_1\) is the principal focus on one side of the lens and \(\mathsf{F}_2\) is the principal focus on the other side of the lens
Two rays from the top of the object are incident on the lens, as shown in Fig. 7.2
The prism refracts the white light
State the name of the effect that produces a spectrum
In the spectrum shown in Fig. 7.3, there are seven colours
List the seven colours in the order they appear between X and Z
X
Z
Fig. 7.3 shows a prism producing a spectrum of colours from a narrow beam of white light
The electromagnet is a temporary magnet
State **one** material which is suitable for the core of the electromagnet
The battery is made from cells connected in series. Each cell in the battery has an electromotive force (e.m.f.) of 1.5V
Calculate the number of cells in the battery in Fig. 8.1
number of cells = .........
There is a magnetic field around the electromagnet
State the name of a piece of equipment that can show the direction of a magnetic field
State the name of the pole labelled X on the core of the electromagnet
The switch is closed. The direction of the current in the solenoid is shown in Fig. 8.1
The resistance of the solenoid is \(8.0 \Omega\)
The current in the solenoid is 1.2A
Calculate the potential difference (p.d.) across the solenoid
Fig. 8.1 shows an arrangement for making an electromagnet. The electromagnet consists of a solenoid and a core
State the name of each of the three wires inside the power cable
The cable is designed for a maximum current of 13A
Suggest one hazard due to a current of 30A in the cable
Fig. 9.1 shows the power cable for connecting a desktop computer to the mains electricity circuit
Calculate the output voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the secondary coil
The current in the input coil of the transformer is 1.4A
Calculate the input power to the desktop computer
input power = .........W
There is a transformer in the desktop computer
The input voltage to the primary coil \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) is \(230\mathrm{V}\) (a.c.)
The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 720
The number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) is 50
Calculate the number of neutrons in one nucleus of strontium-90
number of neutrons = .........
Determine the number of electrons in one atom of strontium-90
number of electrons = .........
Strontium-90 decays by emitting \(\beta\) -particles (beta-particles)
Describe the nature of \(\beta\) -particles
Strontium-90 decays with a half-life of 29 years
A sample contains \(16\mathrm{mg}\) of strontium-90
Calculate the time taken for the strontium-90 to decay until only \(2.0 \text{mg}\) of strontium-90 remains in the sample
time = .........years
A nucleus of strontium-90 is represented using nuclide notation as shown
The Sun is the star in our Solar System. Eight planets orbit the Sun
State the names of two other categories of bodies in the Solar System
State the name of the galaxy that includes our Solar System
Describe how the light from distant galaxies gives evidence to support the Big Bang Theory
